qas.question: A colonist far from the Mediterranean and low in social rank would be more likely to do what?
Greco-Macedonian elites remained commited to what culture?
Who did Greeks look down upon?
Who was the first Ptolemaic ruler to learn the Egyptian language?

context: The trends of Hellenization were therefore accompanied by Greeks adopting native ways over time, but this was widely varied by place and by social class. The farther away from the Mediterranean and the lower in social status, the more likely that a colonist was to <a0_0>adopt local ways<a0_0/>, while the Greco-Macedonian elites and Royal families, usually remained thoroughly <a1_0>Greek<a1_0/> and viewed most <a2_0>non-Greeks<a2_0/> with disdain. It is only until <a3_0>Cleopatra VII<a3_0/>, that a Ptolemaic ruler bothered to learn the Egyptian language of their subjects.
